title: Life, Homeostasis, and Climate as an Engineered Outcome of Living Systems
summary: EarthPulse makes landscape impact on local climate visible through Earth Metrics. This essay explains how living systems regulate climate and why regeneration restores stability.
content:
EarthPulse makes landscape impact on local climate visible through Earth Metrics. This essay explains why living systems regulate climate, how degradation disrupts those feedbacks, and why regeneration restores stability.

Living systems have been affecting the Earth’s climate for billions of years. Their flourishing is not separate from human success; it is one of the most effective tools available to us for cultivating a beautiful, stable, and long-lasting home for our species.

From a systems perspective, this should not be surprising. Systems that persist over time tend to evolve mechanisms that keep key variables within operating limits. Systems without stabilizing feedbacks fail. This principle applies equally to mechanical systems, biological systems, and planetary systems.

Living systems are no exception. At every scale—from cells to forests to watersheds—life actively modifies its environment. It redistributes energy, buffers extremes, and maintains conditions that support continued function. These behaviors are not intentional in the human sense, but they are consistent and repeatable.

When these regulatory mechanisms are disrupted—through soil degradation, loss of vegetation, simplification of structure (clear cutting), or hydrological disconnection—the system becomes unstable. Variability increases. Heat accumulates. Water either floods or disappears. Recovery from stress slows. The environment becomes harder to inhabit, not because the climate has turned hostile on its own, but because the living systems that once moderated it are no longer regulating it as they have been.

From this perspective, climate is not something imposed externally on landscapes. It is something that emerges from them, and is affected by adjacent climates. A climate that supports human societies—moderate temperatures, reliable water availability, and resilience to extremes—is not uniquely human-centric. These same conditions support forests, rivers, insects, and microbial life. There is no meaningful separation between a climate that is good for humans and one that is good for life in general.

This understanding does not require rejecting modern life or technological progress. It simply requires acknowledging that human systems now operate at a scale where they either reinforce or undermine the stabilizing feedbacks life has already built. Land use, infrastructure, agriculture, and energy systems can either participate in regulation or contribute to volatility.

The encouraging reality is that many of life’s regulatory mechanisms are observable, measurable, and reproducible. Vegetated land consistently runs cooler than bare ground. Living soils hold more water than compacted ones. Diverse ecosystems recover from disturbance more reliably than simplified ones. These are empirical observations, not philosophical positions.

There is also a practical beauty in systems that function well. As writers like Carl Safina have noted, beauty often arises from coherence and integrity rather than ornament. Healthy landscapes are compelling because their flows make sense: water moves predictably, energy is dissipated rather than trapped, and relationships between components are intact. The visual order we associate with beauty is often the visible signature of a system operating within its design limits.

Seen this way, participating in life’s regulatory processes is not about nostalgia or retreat. It is about engineering with better boundary conditions. It is about designing human activity in a way that aligns with the feedbacks that have made Earth habitable in the first place.

Climate stability is not a mystery and not a miracle. It is a systems outcome. When living processes are intact, climate tends toward moderation. When they are removed, climate becomes erratic. Recognizing this gives us a practical path forward: not controlling the planet, but restoring and reinforcing the mechanisms that already know how to keep it livable.

That is not a spiritual project. It is an engineering challenge—one that life has been solving successfully for a very long time. It is our turn. EarthPulse seeks to provide a venue for the incredible data that we as a species have collected. From the aggregation of that data it will provide the ability for our intelligence to act on this complex system and find ways to harmonize and create beauty.

title: Why We Need to Practice Imagining a Better Future
summary: A vision of cooperative, regenerative futures and why EarthPulse is built to support them.
imageAlt: Illustration of regenerative city planning, farming, watershed management, and classroom learning.
content:
I made this image to give a little more shape to a future I want to help build. It is an AI-generated image, and I do not pretend it is a blueprint or a prediction. But it captures something that feels important to articulate: a vision of people working together across disciplines, across cultures, across ways of being—using technology not to dominate, but to understand; not to extract, but to coordinate; not to isolate, but to cooperate.

We are very good, as a culture, at communicating dystopias. We can vividly imagine collapse, alienation, environmental breakdown, and social fragmentation. Those stories are everywhere, and to be fair, many of them are grounded in real risks. But if we only practice imagining failure, it becomes much easier to slip into despair, numbness, or short-term maximizing behavior—doing whatever feels good or profitable right now because the future feels abstract or doomed anyway. I do not think that is a healthy place to live from.

I am still interested in living as if the seeds I plant are going to grow. As if what I do matters not just for me, but for my kids, for the people I will never meet, and for the many lives—human and non-human—that I pass through along the way.

In it, you see regenerative farmers using advanced tools while standing in living landscapes. You see city planners mixing ecological literacy with high-tech infrastructure. You see hydrologists working with watersheds as systems, not problems to be managed away. You see classrooms where kids are learning about Earth as a living system they participate in, not a resource they inherit by accident.

A cooperative human civilization will not come from a single aesthetic, ideology, or personality type. It will come from learning how to work together across differences—how to value both technical rigor and lived experience, both data and intuition, both structure and creativity.

It will also require rethinking how we interact with the Earth, especially through our food systems. Agriculture sits at the intersection of climate, water, culture, and daily life. The way we grow food shapes landscapes, communities, and feedback loops that either stabilize or destabilize the systems we depend on. A regenerative food system is not just about yields or carbon—it is about relationship, resilience, and long-term stewardship.

And yes, beauty matters too. Not beauty as decoration, but beauty as coherence. There is something deeply motivating about environments—natural or human-made—that feel like they make sense. Where flows are visible. Where systems feel alive and responsive rather than brittle and extractive. Beauty, in that sense, is often a signal that something is working.

EarthPulse exists because I believe we need better tools to support this kind of future. Tools that help us see the Earth clearly. Tools that translate complex data into signals we can understand and act on. Tools that support cooperation rather than competition, long-term thinking rather than short-term optimization.

This image is not saying this is inevitable. It is saying this is possible. And I think it is worth practicing imagining that possibility—giving it form, color, and narrative—so we have something to move toward. In the absence of a shared, compelling vision, it is far too easy to drift. To disengage. To assume nothing we do really matters.

I do not buy that. I am still into showing up as if the future is shaped by what we choose to build together. This image is one small expression of that commitment—and an invitation to keep imagining, designing, and planting seeds for a civilization that knows how to cooperate with itself and with the living world it depends on.

title: The Regen Registry: Holding the Stories of Regeneration
summary: Why the Regen Registry exists, how it connects stories to Earth Metrics, and why regeneration needs a shared, visible map.
imageAlt: Illustration of the Regen Registry as a living library of global regeneration efforts.
content:
Ever since I first heard about regeneration projects through Neal Spackman’s video on the Al-Baydha project—greening a harsh desert with less than three inches of rain per year—I have felt deeply moved to joy. That story stayed with me. It gave me something to respond with when faced with the many accounts of humans degrading land and harming ecosystems.

Stories of overgrazed landscapes, drying watersheds, polluted rivers, and degraded farms are everywhere. Those outcomes come from destructive and understandable habits—ways of interacting with land that evolved under pressure, scarcity, or incomplete understanding. The Al-Baydha project made me realize that there is another way of going about things. A way that allows systems to flourish—in health, beauty, and productivity and that's better for humans and the rest of life.

That alternative didn’t come from force or grand intervention. It came from time, care, and real attention. From learning how rain fell in that place, how water moved across the land, how soil functioned, how vegetation responded to small rock dams placed with intention. From working with the system instead of against it.

Regeneration stories remind me that our capacity for destruction is only matched by our capacity for creation. The same species capable of stripping landscapes can also restore and even enrich them. The difference is not power. It is understanding, intention, and patience. That realization sits at the heart of why the Regen Registry exists.

The Regen Registry is not a scorecard or a ranking. It is a living library of regeneration efforts around the world—real places, stewarded by real people, working with Earth’s systems rather than against them. It is a place to hold the stories, contexts, and geographies of regeneration so they do not remain isolated anecdotes scattered across papers, podcasts, and word of mouth.

Regeneration is happening everywhere, but it often feels invisible. Projects are separated by geography, by discipline, by language. Farmers rarely see what hydrologists are doing upstream. City planners do not often hear about land restoration happening just beyond their boundaries. Educators struggle to point to concrete, place-based examples that show what cooperation with living systems actually looks like. The Regen Registry is meant to change that.

At its simplest, it is a map—a way to see where regeneration is happening. A map to celebrate the efforts of system thinkers and stewards who are improving our shared future. A map to connect people with projects they may want to support, learn from, or be inspired by.

What unites these projects is not ideology. It is curiosity. A willingness to ask better questions. To observe before and after intervening. To accept that living systems are complex, adaptive, and powerful—not fragile abstractions, but dynamic systems worthy of respect.

Again and again, the same pattern emerges: when we take the time to understand Earth’s systems—water cycles, soil biology, vegetation dynamics, energy flows—and then the design interventions that support those systems emerge. Life responds to them, productivity increases, volatility decreases, and resilience grows. This is not romanticism. It is systems behavior.

The Regen Registry exists because these stories matter—not just emotionally, but practically. They show what is possible when humans participate as learners and collaborators rather than controllers. They provide reference points, inspiration, and, eventually, a basis for comparison of various interventions.

There is also something deeply grounding about seeing these projects together. About realizing that while the challenges we face are real and global, so is the work of repair. That people across cultures, climates, and disciplines are choosing creation over extraction, coherence over chaos.

EarthPulse provides the tools to measure and visualize Earth’s systems. The Regen Registry provides the human context—the places where care meets understanding, and understanding becomes action. As the software evolves, this registry will be directly linked to analysis. Users will be able to select a regeneration project and be brought to its location in the EarthPulse explorer, with relevant time scales and metrics preloaded.

Together, EarthPulse and the Regen Registry form a bridge between data and meaning. Between signal and story. Between what is broken and what is being rebuilt.

For me, the Regen Registry is an expression of belief: that paying attention matters, that learning leads somewhere, and that when we align human intelligence with the intelligence already present in living systems, both Earth and humanity can flourish together. That is a story worth holding onto. And it is one worth growing.
